text:
<task_description>

# Code Change Workflow

Your task is to guide the user through code changes using a series of steps. Each step should describe a high-level change, which can consist of multiple edits to distinct locations in the codebase.

## Output Example

Provide output as XML, with the following format:

<step>
Update the Person struct to store an age

```rust
struct Person {
    // existing fields...
    age: u8,
    height: f32,
    // existing fields...
}

impl Person {
    fn age(&self) -> u8 {
        self.age
    }
}
```

<edit>
<path>src/person.rs</path>
<operation>insert_before</operation>
<search>height: f32,</search>
<description>Add the age field</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/person.rs</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search>impl Person {</search>
<description>Add the age getter</description>
</edit>
</step>

## Output Format

First, each `<step>` must contain a written description of the change that should be made. The description should begin with a high-level overview, and can contain markdown code blocks as well. The description should be self-contained and actionable.

After the description, each `<step>` must contain one or more `<edit>` tags, each of which refer to a specific range in a source file. Each `<edit>` tag must contain the following child tags:

### `<path>` (required)

This tag contains the path to the file that will be changed. It can be an existing path, or a path that should be created.

### `<search>` (optional)

This tag contains a search string to locate in the source file, e.g. `pub fn baz() {`. If not provided, the new content will be inserted at the top of the file. Make sure to produce a string that exists in the source file and that isn't ambiguous. When there's ambiguity, add more lines to the search to eliminate it.

### `<description>` (required)

This tag contains a single-line description of the edit that should be made at the given location.

### `<operation>` (required)

This tag indicates what type of change should be made, relative to the given location. It can be one of the following:
- `update`: Rewrites the specified string entirely based on the given description.
- `create`: Creates a new file with the given path based on the provided description.
- `insert_before`: Inserts new text based on the given description before the specified search string.
- `insert_after`: Inserts new text based on the given description after the specified search string.
- `delete`: Deletes the specified string from the containing file.

<guidelines>
- There's no need to describe *what* to do, just *where* to do it.
- Only reference locations that actually exist (unless you're creating a file).
- If creating a file, assume any subsequent updates are included at the time of creation.
- Don't create and then update a file. Always create new files in one hot.
- Prefer multiple edits to smaller regions, as opposed to one big edit to a larger region.
- Don't produce edits that intersect each other. In that case, merge them into a bigger edit.
- Never nest an edit with another edit. Never include CDATA. All edits are leaf nodes.
- Descriptions are required for all edits except delete.
- When generating multiple edits, ensure the descriptions are specific to each individual operation.
- Avoid referring to the search string in the description. Focus on the change to be made, not the location where it's made. That's implicit with the `search` string you provide.
- Don't generate multiple edits at the same location. Instead, combine them together in a single edit with a succinct combined description.
- Always ensure imports are added if you're referencing symbols that are not in scope.
</guidelines>

Here are some concrete examples.

<example>
<message role="user">

```rs src/shapes.rs
pub mod rectangle;
pub mod circle;
```

```rs src/shapes/rectangle.rs
pub struct Rectangle {
    width: f64,
    height: f64,
}

impl Rectangle {
    pub fn new(width: f64, height: f64) -> Self {
        Rectangle { width, height }
    }
}
```

```rs src/shapes/circle.rs
pub struct Circle {
    radius: f64,
}

impl Circle {
    pub fn new(radius: f64) -> Self {
        Circle { radius }
    }
}
```

Update all shapes to store their origin as an (x, y) tuple and implement Display.
</message>

<message role="assistant">
We'll need to update both the rectangle and circle modules.

<step>
Add origin fields to both shape types.

```rust
struct Rectangle {
    // existing fields ...
    origin: (f64, f64),
}
```

```rust
struct Circle {
    // existing fields ...
    origin: (f64, f64),
}
```

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/rectangle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_before</operation>
<search>
    width: f64,
    height: f64,
</search>
<description>Add the origin field to Rectangle</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/circle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_before</operation>
<search>
    radius: f64,
</search>
<description>Add the origin field to Circle</description>
</edit>

<step>
Update both shape's constructors to take an origin.

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/rectangle.rs</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
    fn new(width: f64, height: f64) -> Self {
        Rectangle { width, height }
    }
</search>
<description>Update the Rectangle new function to take an origin</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/circle.rs</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
    fn new(radius: f64) -> Self {
        Circle { radius }
    }
</search>
<description>Update the Circle new function to take an origin</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Implement Display for both shapes

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/rectangle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_before</operation>
<search>
struct Rectangle {
</search>
<description>Add an import for the `std::fmt` module</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/rectangle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search>
        Rectangle { width, height }
    }
}
</search>
<description>Add a Display implementation for Rectangle</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/circle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_before</operation>
<search>
struct Circle {
</search>
<description>Add an import for the `std::fmt` module</description>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/shapes/circle.rs</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search>
        Circle { radius }
    }
}
</search>
<description>Add a Display implementation for Circle</description>
</edit>
</step>
</message>
</example>

<example number=2>
<message role="user">

```rs src/user.rs
struct User {
    pub name: String,
    age: u32,
    email: String,
}

impl User {
    fn new(name: String, age: u32, email: String) -> Self {
        User { name, age, email }
    }

    pub fn print_info(&self) {
        todo!()
    }
}
```

Let's print all the user information and delete the email field.
</message>

<message role="assistant">
<step>
Update the 'print_info' method to print user information

```rust
impl User {
    // ... other methods ...

    pub fn print_info(&self) {
        println!("Name: {name}, Age: {age}", name = self.name, age = self.age);
    }
}
```

<edit>
<path>src/user.rs</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
    pub fn print_info(&self) {
        todo!()
    }
</search>
<description>Print all the user information</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Remove the 'email' field from the User struct

<edit>
<path>src/user.rs</path>
<operation>delete</operation>
<search>
email: String,
</search>
</edit>

<edit>
<path>src/user.rs</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<symbol>
fn new(name: String, age: u32, email: String) -> Self {
    User { name, age, email }
}
</symbol>
<description>Remove email parameter from new method</description>
</edit>
</step>
</message>
</example>

You should think step by step. When possible, produce smaller, coherent logical steps as opposed to one big step that combines lots of heterogeneous edits.

</task_description>



loantracker/
```loantracker/.gitignore
.DS_Store
/.build
/Packages
xcuserdata/
DerivedData/
.swiftpm/configuration/registries.json
.swiftpm/xcode/package.xcworkspace/contents.xcworkspacedata
.netrc
```

```swift loantracker/Package.swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
// The swift-tools-version declares the minimum version of Swift required to build this package.

import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    targets: [
        // Targets are the basic building blocks of a package, defining a module or a test suite.
        // Targets can depend on other targets in this package and products from dependencies.
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker"),
    ]
)
```

Sources
```swift loantracker/Sources/main.swift
// The Swift Programming Language
// https://docs.swift.org/swift-book

print("Hello, world!")
```



Let's turn this into a SwiftUI app for Mac.
Certainly! I'll guide you through the process of turning this into a SwiftUI app for Mac. We'll do this in several steps.

<step>
Update the Package.swift file to include the necessary dependencies and targets for a SwiftUI Mac app.

```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker",
            dependencies: []),
    ]
)
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Package.swift</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
// The swift-tools-version declares the minimum version of Swift required to build this package.

import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    targets: [
        // Targets are the basic building blocks of a package, defining a module or a test suite.
        // Targets can depend on other targets in this package and products from dependencies.
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker"),
    ]
)
</search>
<description>Update Package.swift for SwiftUI Mac app</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Create a new file for the main app structure.

```swift
import SwiftUI

@main
struct LoanTrackerApp: App {
    var body: some Scene {
        WindowGroup {
            ContentView()
        }
    }
}
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Sources/LoanTrackerApp.swift</path>
<operation>create</operation>
<description>Create the main app structure file</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Create a new file for the main content view.

```swift
import SwiftUI

struct ContentView: View {
    var body: some View {
        Text("Hello, Loan Tracker!")
            .padding()
    }
}

struct ContentView_Previews: PreviewProvider {
    static var previews: some View {
        ContentView()
    }
}
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Sources/ContentView.swift</path>
<operation>create</operation>
<description>Create the main content view file</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Update the main.swift file to be empty, as it's no longer needed for a SwiftUI app.

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Sources/main.swift</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
// The Swift Programming Language
// https://docs.swift.org/swift-book

print("Hello, world!")
</search>
<description>Clear the contents of main.swift</description>
</edit>
</step>

These changes will transform your project into a basic SwiftUI app for Mac. The app doesn't have any loan tracking functionality yet, but it provides the foundation for building a Mac app using SwiftUI.
/terminal Certainly! To interact with the terminal and test our SwiftUI Mac app, you can follow these steps:

1. First, make sure you're in the project directory:

```
cd loantracker
```

2. Build the project:

```
swift build
```

3. Run the app:

```
swift run
```

If everything is set up correctly, this should launch your SwiftUI Mac app. You should see a window with the text "Hello, Loan Tracker!" displayed.

If you encounter any issues or need to make further changes, please let me know, and I'll be happy to help you troubleshoot or guide you through additional modifications.


Thank you for providing those terminal instructions. Let's go ahead and try building and running the app to see if everything is working as expected.

<step>
Build and run the SwiftUI Mac app

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Build and run the SwiftUI Mac app</description>
</edit>
</step>

Please execute the following commands in the terminal and let me know the output:

```
cd loantracker
swift build
swift run
```

Once you've run these commands, please provide me with the results, including any error messages if they occur. This will help us determine if the app is working correctly or if we need to make any adjustments.

Thank you for providing the terminal output. It appears we're encountering an error due to the presence of both a `main.swift` file and the `@main` attribute in our `LoanTrackerApp.swift` file. Let's resolve this issue by removing the `main.swift` file entirely, as it's not needed for our SwiftUI app.

<step>
Remove the main.swift file

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Remove the main.swift file</description>
</edit>
</step>

Please execute the following command in the terminal:

```
rm loantracker/Sources/main.swift
```

After removing the `main.swift` file, let's try building and running the app again.

<step>
Rebuild and run the SwiftUI Mac app

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Rebuild and run the SwiftUI Mac app</description>
</edit>
</step>

Please execute the following commands:

```
swift build
swift run
```

Please provide the output of these commands. If we still encounter any issues, we'll address them in the next step.
it built, but the app didn't show a UI, no errors on the console.
Thank you for the update. It's good news that the app built successfully, but we need to address the issue of the UI not showing up. This is likely because we're building a command-line tool instead of a proper macOS app. Let's modify our project to create a macOS app bundle.

<step>
Update Package.swift to create a macOS app bundle

We need to modify the Package.swift file to specify that we're creating a macOS application.

```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker",
            dependencies: [],
            swiftSettings: [
                .unsafeFlags(["-parse-as-library"])
            ]
        )
    ]
)
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Package.swift</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker",
            dependencies: []),
    ]
)
</search>
<description>Update Package.swift to create a macOS app bundle</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Create an Info.plist file

We need to create an Info.plist file to properly configure our macOS app.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>CFBundleDevelopmentRegion</key>
    <string>$(DEVELOPMENT_LANGUAGE)</string>
    <key>CFBundleExecutable</key>
    <string>$(EXECUTABLE_NAME)</string>
    <key>CFBundleIconFile</key>
    <string></string>
    <key>CFBundleIdentifier</key>
    <string>$(PRODUCT_BUNDLE_IDENTIFIER)</string>
    <key>CFBundleInfoDictionaryVersion</key>
    <string>6.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleName</key>
    <string>$(PRODUCT_NAME)</string>
    <key>CFBundlePackageType</key>
    <string>$(PRODUCT_BUNDLE_PACKAGE_TYPE)</string>
    <key>CFBundleShortVersionString</key>
    <string>1.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleVersion</key>
    <string>1</string>
    <key>LSMinimumSystemVersion</key>
    <string>$(MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET)</string>
    <key>NSHumanReadableCopyright</key>
    <string></string>
    <key>NSMainStoryboardFile</key>
    <string>Main</string>
    <key>NSPrincipalClass</key>
    <string>NSApplication</string>
</dict>
</plist>
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Sources/Info.plist</path>
<operation>create</operation>
<description>Create Info.plist file for macOS app</description>
</edit>
</step>

Now, let's rebuild and run the app using Xcode, which will properly handle the app bundle creation.

<step>
Generate Xcode project and open it

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Generate Xcode project and open it</description>
</edit>
</step>

Please run the following commands in the terminal:

```
swift package generate-xcodeproj
open loantracker.xcodeproj
```

Once Xcode opens:

1. Select the "loantracker" scheme in the top left corner.
2. Choose "My Mac" as the run destination.
3. Click the "Run" button (play icon) or press Cmd+R to build and run the app.

After following these steps, the app should launch with a visible UI. Please let me know if you see the "Hello, Loan Tracker!" message in a window, or if you encounter any issues.

I apologize for the confusion. It seems there was an error in the Package.swift file that I didn't catch earlier. Let's fix this issue and try again.

<step>
Update Package.swift to correctly define the macOS application

```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "loantracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    products: [
        .executable(name: "LoanTracker", targets: ["loantracker"])
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker",
            dependencies: [],
            swiftSettings: [
                .unsafeFlags(["-parse-as-library"])
            ]
        )
    ]
)
```

<edit>
<path>loantracker/Package.swift</path>
<operation>update</operation>
<search>

    name: "loantracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "loantracker",
            dependencies: [],
            swiftSettings: [
                .unsafeFlags(["-parse-as-library"])
            ]
        )
    ]
)
</search>
<description>Update Package.swift to correctly define the macOS application</description>
</edit>
</step>

Now that we've corrected the Package.swift file, let's try to generate the Xcode project again.

<step>
Generate Xcode project and open it

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Generate Xcode project and open it</description>
</edit>
</step>

Please run the following commands in the terminal:

```
swift package generate-xcodeproj
open loantracker.xcodeproj
```

Once Xcode opens:

1. Select the "loantracker" scheme in the top left corner.
2. Choose "My Mac" as the run destination.
3. Click the "Run" button (play icon) or press Cmd+R to build and run the app.

After following these steps, the app should launch with a visible UI. Please let me know if you see the "Hello, Loan Tracker!" message in a window, or if you encounter any issues.

I apologize for the confusion. It seems that the `swift package generate-xcodeproj` command is no longer available in the version of Swift you're using. Let's take a different approach to create an Xcode project for our SwiftUI Mac app.

<step>
Create a new Xcode project for the SwiftUI Mac app

1. Open Xcode
2. Choose "Create a new Xcode project"
3. Select "macOS" at the top
4. Choose "App" as the template
5. Click "Next"
6. Set the following details:
   - Product Name: LoanTracker
   - Team: Your personal team (if available)
   - Organization Identifier: com.example (or your preferred identifier)
   - Interface: SwiftUI
   - Language: Swift
7. Click "Next"
8. Choose a location to save the project (preferably next to your current loantracker folder)
9. Click "Create"

</edit>

2. Copy `ContentView.swift` and `LoanTrackerApp.swift` files
3. In Xcode, right-click on the LoanTracker folder in the project navigator
4. Choose "Add Files to 'LoanTracker'..."
5. Navigate to where you copied the files and select them
6. Ensure "Copy items if needed" is checked
7. Click "Add"

)

I apologize for the confusion. The issue is that we're still building a command-line tool rather than a proper macOS application bundle. To create a SwiftUI Mac app without Xcode, we need to take a slightly different approach. Let's modify our setup to create an application bundle.

<step>
Update Package.swift to include necessary flags for creating a macOS app bundle

```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "LoanTracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    products: [
        .executable(name: "LoanTracker", targets: ["LoanTracker"])
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "LoanTracker",
            dependencies: [],
            resources: [.process("Resources")],
            swiftSettings: [
                .unsafeFlags([
                    "-framework", "AppKit",
                    "-framework", "SwiftUI"
                ])
            ],
            linkerSettings: [
                .unsafeFlags([
                    "-Xlinker", "-application_extension",
                    "-Xlinker", "-framework", "-Xlinker", "AppKit",
                    "-Xlinker", "-framework", "-Xlinker", "SwiftUI"
                ])
            ]
        )
    ]
)
```

<step>
Create a main.swift file to initialize the application

Create a new file `main.swift` in the `Sources/LoanTracker` directory with the following content:

```swift
import AppKit

let app = NSApplication.shared
let delegate = AppDelegate()
app.delegate = delegate
app.run()

class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ notification: Notification) {
        let window = NSWindow(
            contentRect: NSRect(x: 100, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
            styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
            backing: .buffered,
            defer: false
        )
        window.title = "Loan Tracker"
        window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
        
        let hostingView = NSHostingView(rootView: ContentView())
        window.contentView = hostingView
    }
}
```

I apologize for the confusion. It seems we need to adjust our approach to work with Swift's top-level code restrictions and concurrency rules. Let's modify our `main.swift` file to address these issues.

<step>
Update main.swift to comply with Swift's top-level code restrictions and concurrency rules

```swift
import AppKit
import SwiftUI

@main
struct LoanTrackerApp {
    static func main() {
        let app = NSApplication.shared
        let delegate = AppDelegate()
        app.delegate = delegate
        app.run()
    }
}

class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    var window: NSWindow!

    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ notification: Notification) {
        window = NSWindow(
            contentRect: NSRect(x: 100, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
            styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
            backing: .buffered,
            defer: false
        )
        window.title = "Loan Tracker"
        window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
        
        let contentView = NSHostingView(rootView: ContentView())
        window.contentView = contentView
    }
}
```

Now, we need to create a shell script that will build and run our app as a proper macOS application bundle.

<step>
Create a build and run script

Create a new file called `build_and_run.sh` in the root of your project with the following content:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

set -e

# Build the project
swift build -c release

# Create app bundle structure
APP_NAME="LoanTracker"
APP_BUNDLE="${APP_NAME}.app"
CONTENTS_DIR="${APP_BUNDLE}/Contents"
MACOS_DIR="${CONTENTS_DIR}/MacOS"
RESOURCES_DIR="${CONTENTS_DIR}/Resources"

mkdir -p "${MACOS_DIR}" "${RESOURCES_DIR}"

# Copy executable
cp .build/release/${APP_NAME} "${MACOS_DIR}/"

# Create Info.plist
cat > "${CONTENTS_DIR}/Info.plist" << EOF
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>CFBundleExecutable</key>
    <string>${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundleIconFile</key>
    <string></string>
    <key>CFBundleIdentifier</key>
    <string>com.example.${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundleInfoDictionaryVersion</key>
    <string>6.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleName</key>
    <string>${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundlePackageType</key>
    <string>APPL</string>
    <key>CFBundleShortVersionString</key>
    <string>1.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleVersion</key>
    <string>1</string>
    <key>NSPrincipalClass</key>
    <string>NSApplication</string>
    <key>NSSupportsAutomaticTermination</key>
    <true/>
    <key>NSSupportsSuddenTermination</key>
    <true/>
</dict>
</plist>
EOF

# Run the app
open "${APP_BUNDLE}"
```

<path>loantracker/build_and_run.sh</path>
<operation>create</operation>
<description>Create build_and_run.sh script</description>
</edit>
</step>

<step>
Make the script executable and run it

<edit>
<path>terminal</path>
<operation>insert_after</operation>
<search></search>
<description>Make the script executable and run it</description>
</edit>
</step>

Run the following commands in the terminal:

```
chmod +x build_and_run.sh
./build_and_run.sh
```

This script will build your project, create a proper macOS app bundle, and then launch the app. You should now see a window appear with the "Hello, Loan Tracker!" message.

If you still encounter issues, please provide the output of these commands, and we'll continue to troubleshoot.

<step>
Update Package.swift to include SwiftUI

```swift
// swift-tools-version: 6.0
import PackageDescription

let package = Package(
    name: "LoanTracker",
    platforms: [
        .macOS(.v13)
    ],
    products: [
        .executable(name: "LoanTracker", targets: ["LoanTracker"])
    ],
    dependencies: [
        .package(url: "https://github.com/apple/swift-ui.git", from: "1.0.0")
    ],
    targets: [
        .executableTarget(
            name: "LoanTracker",
            dependencies: [.product(name: "SwiftUI", package: "swift-ui")],
            resources: [.process("Resources")]
        )
    ]
)
```

<step>
Update main.swift to use @NSApplicationMain

```swift
import SwiftUI

@NSApplicationMain
class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    var window: NSWindow!

    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ aNotification: Notification) {
        let contentView = ContentView()

        window = NSWindow(
            contentRect: NSRect(x: 100, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
            styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
            backing: .buffered,
            defer: false)
        window.title = "Loan Tracker"
        window.center()
        window.setFrameAutosaveName("Main Window")
        window.contentView = NSHostingView(rootView: contentView)
        window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
    }

    func applicationWillTerminate(_ aNotification: Notification) {
        // Insert code here to tear down your application
    }
}
```

<step>
Update build_and_run.sh script

```bash
#!/bin/bash

set -e

# Build the project
swift build -c release

# Create app bundle structure
APP_NAME="LoanTracker"
APP_BUNDLE="${APP_NAME}.app"
CONTENTS_DIR="${APP_BUNDLE}/Contents"
MACOS_DIR="${CONTENTS_DIR}/MacOS"
RESOURCES_DIR="${CONTENTS_DIR}/Resources"

mkdir -p "${MACOS_DIR}" "${RESOURCES_DIR}"

# Copy executable
cp .build/release/${APP_NAME} "${MACOS_DIR}/"

# Create Info.plist
cat > "${CONTENTS_DIR}/Info.plist" << EOF
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>CFBundleExecutable</key>
    <string>${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundleIconFile</key>
    <string></string>
    <key>CFBundleIdentifier</key>
    <string>com.example.${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundleInfoDictionaryVersion</key>
    <string>6.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleName</key>
    <string>${APP_NAME}</string>
    <key>CFBundlePackageType</key>
    <string>APPL</string>
    <key>CFBundleShortVersionString</key>
    <string>1.0</string>
    <key>CFBundleVersion</key>
    <string>1</string>
    <key>NSPrincipalClass</key>
    <string>NSApplication</string>
    <key>NSSupportsAutomaticTermination</key>
    <true/>
    <key>NSSupportsSuddenTermination</key>
    <true/>
    <key>LSMinimumSystemVersion</key>
    <string>13.0</string>
</dict>
</plist>
EOF

# Run the app
open "${APP_BUNDLE}"
```

```swift
import SwiftUI
import AppKit

@NSApplicationMain
class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    var window: NSWindow!

    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ aNotification: Notification) {
        let contentView = ContentView()

        window = NSWindow(
            contentRect: NSRect(x: 100, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
            styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
            backing: .buffered,
            defer: false)
        window.title = "Loan Tracker"
        window.center()
        window.setFrameAutosaveName("Main Window")
        window.contentView = NSHostingView(rootView: contentView)
        window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
    }

    func applicationWillTerminate(_ aNotification: Notification) {
        // Insert code here to tear down your application
    }
}
```
